hedline.hl1: Hypertext Authors Meet The Pen and Ink Crowd

abstract.p: Editors of The Paris Review gather in New York with members of Electronic Literature Organization, a new group founded to support works of hypertext writers, which invite the reader to charter their own paths through stories by clicking on seemingly random words on their computer screen (S)

block.p: Two divergent literary groups converged this month on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. One was made up of the editors of The Paris Review, a distinguished quarterly of literature and poetry. The other was the Electronic Literature Organization, a new group founded to support the works of hypertext authors. A quirky clan of writers who write for the computer screens, hypertext authors invite readers to chart their own paths through stories by clicking on seemingly random words.

The gathering, with George Plimpton as host, was something of a coming out party for the hypertext crowd, said Robert Coover, an author of traditional novels and a champion of new media. Amid wall-to-wall bookshelves on the second floor of the Paris Review's offices, Mr. Coover and other E.L.O. founders used a slide-show screen and laptop computer to project images of the E.L.O.'s Web site (www.eliterature.org) and samples of previous hypertext projects.

The gathering, with George Plimpton as host, was something of a coming out party for the hypertext crowd, said Robert Coover, an author of traditional novels and a champion of new media. Amid wall-to-wall bookshelves on the second floor of the Paris Review's offices, Mr. Coover and other E.L.O. founders used a slide-show screen and laptop computer to project images of the E.L.O.'s Web site (www.eliterature.org) and samples of previous hypertext projects.
Some members of the audience, whose eyes were wandering, did not appear to be immediately persuaded. But at least, some hypertext authors said, they were getting a glimpse.
The next step is to try to get traditional writers interested in embarking on what Mr. Plimpton called a field of writing that he knew ''nothing about.''
